description: From Middle English tin, from Old English tin, from Proto-West Germanic *tin, from Proto-Germanic *tinÄ….

entries.meaning: Made of galvanised iron or built of corrugated iron.
examples: [I]n fact he was a big noise, literally, in the Baptist Chapel, known locally as the Tin Tab[ernacle] - whereas my family were 'church' and Uncle Ezekiel was an infidel at that.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A malleable, ductile, metallic element, resistant to corrosion, with atomic number 50 and symbol Sn.
(New Zealand, Australia, South Africa, Ireland, Britain, countable) An airtight container, made of tin or another metal, used to preserve food, or hold a liquid or some other product.
examples: a tin of baked beans; a tobacco tin; a tin of shoe polish
Several tins of paint were needed to paint the house.
empty tins, cans, and plastic containers are recycled in the blue bins.

entries.meaning: (countable) A metal pan used for baking, roasting, etc.
(countable, squash) The bottom part of the front wall, which is "out" if a player strikes it with the ball.
(slang, dated, uncountable) money, especially silver money.
examples: The father is a cotton lord, and they all have loads of tin, you know

verbs.description: tin (third-person singular simple present tins, present participle tinning, simple past and past participle tinned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place into a metal can (ie. a tin; be it tin, steel, aluminum) in order to preserve.
To coat with solder, in preparation for soldering, to ensure a good solder joint
To coat with solder, in order to consolidate braided wire, so as to make contact with all strands and reduce fragility of the fraying wire
